title: Breonna Taylor Grand Juror Says Jury Wasn't Given Option to Consider Additional Charges
summary: The anonymous juror filed suit to speak publicly. LOUISVILLE, Ky-A grand juror who won a court fight to speak publicly about the Breonna Taylor investigation took issue Tuesday with statements by Kentucky's attorney general and said the jury wasn't given the option to consider charges connected to Ms. Taylor's shooting death by police.

title: University of Miami Becomes Latest Battleground Over Facial Recognition
summary: Use of the technology on college campuses is drawing criticisms from privacy advocates and some lawmakers. The University of Miami in recent days rebutted claims it uses facial-recognition technology after students accused campus police of using the tool to identify them at a protest related to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Lockheed Martin Plans to Deliver New Presidential Helicopter Next Year
summary: Defense contractor projects modest sales gains despite pressures weighing on military spending. Lockheed Martin Corp. said it expects to deliver the first new presidential helicopter next year as part of a $5 billion refreshing of the White House fleet, part of a modest rise in military spending that the company anticipates in coming years.

title: Snapchat Nears 250 Million Daily Users as Advertisers Lift Spending
summary: Snap's revenue rose to $678.7 million, well ahead of analysts' estimates. Snap Inc.'s revenue surged in the latest quarter, as the company attracted more users to Snapchat as well as advertisers looking to reach people spending more time online and on mobile devices as a result of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Top Universities Took Billions in Unreported Foreign Funds, U.S. Finds
summary: Education Department crackdown yields disclosures by schools including Cornell. Cornell University initially failed to report to U.S. authorities more than $1.2 billion in foreign funds it has received in recent years, including $760 million related to its campus in Qatar and about $1 million in contracts from Chinese telecom company Huawei Technologies Co., the U.S. Education Department indicated in its latest report on schools and foreign contracts.

title: Apollo Board Panel to Review Leon Black Ties With Jeffrey Epstein
summary: Law firm Dechert is selected to examine private-equity firm CEO's dealings with disgraced financier. A group of Apollo Global Management Inc.'s independent board members will review Chief Executive Leon Black's relationship with disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: GMC's All-Electric Hummer Pickup Highlights GM's New Strategy on EVs
summary: After years of selling small cars for masses, company's latest electric entries get bigger, go up market. General Motors Co. spent a decade trying to sell mainstream buyers on electric vehicles by offering small, plug-in cars with quirky names like the Spark and Volt.

title: Trump Urges Barr to Initiate Investigation Into Joe Biden and Son
summary: President increases calls for probes of rival as other inquiries fail to produce indictments or show wrongdoing. WASHINGTON-President Trump urged Attorney General William Barr to initiate an investigation into former Vice President Joe Biden and his son Hunter, escalating his efforts to discredit his Democratic opponent two weeks before the election.

title: GOP Fundraiser Elliott Broidy Pleads Guilty in Case Linked to 1MDB Fund
summary: Broidy admits to conspiring to influence Justice Department's fraud investigation into the Malaysian sovereign-wealth fund. Republican fundraiser Elliott Broidy pleaded guilty to conspiring to violate a foreign-lobbying law, admitting he was paid millions of dollars to lobby on behalf of a businessman accused of masterminding a multibillion-dollar fraud at Malaysian fund 1MDB.

title: DOJ Files Google Antitrust Lawsuit
summary: Resume Subscription. The Justice Department filed a long-expected antitrust lawsuit alleging that Google uses anticompetitive tactics to preserve a monopoly for its flagship search engine and related advertising business, the most aggressive U.S. legal challenge to a company's dominance in the tech sector in more than two decades.

title: Pioneer Natural Resources to Buy Parsley Energy for $4.5 Billion
summary: Deal is latest combination in hard-hit U.S. shale-oil patch, but some warn consolidation may be limited to top-tier firms. Pioneer Natural Resources Co. has agreed to buy Parsley Energy Inc. for $4.5 billion, the latest in a flurry of U.S. oil tie-ups as companies seek to weather low prices brought about by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: The Bidens and China Business
summary: The story won't go away without explanation, even if the Veep wins.. Most of the media is ignoring the emails found in Hunter Biden's laptop, but that doesn't mean they aren't news. Joe Biden has an obligation to answer questions about his son's influence-peddling and his own financial dealings-notably regarding China.

title: NASA's Osiris-REx Mission Aims to Return Samples From Asteroid's Surface
summary: Spacecraft brushes the rubbled surface of Bennu, 200 million miles away. Far from Earth, a U.S. spacecraft gently brushed the face of an asteroid named Bennu on Tuesday in an attempt to pick up and return primordial grit, the first such U.S. mission to try to bring back clues on the origins of the planets from an asteroid's surface.

title: The Supreme Court's Election Dodge
summary: Pennsylvania's ballot extension could haunt the Justices on Nov. 4.. How's this for anticlimactic? The Supreme Court had an appeal from Pennsylvania Republicans for three weeks. State law unambiguously says that mail-in votes are due at 8 p.m. on Election Day. But the Pennsylvania Supreme Court pushed that deadline back to Nov. 6, even if the ballot lacks any legible postmark.

title: Google in the Antitrust Dock
summary: Justice will need more proof of consumer harm to win its lawsuit.. The Justice Department on Tuesday rolled out its first major antitrust lawsuit against Big Tech, and target one is Google. The search giant makes a ripe political target, but on the evidence in the lawsuit the government's claims will be hard to prove.

title: A Debate Downgrade for Foreign Policy
summary: The candidates will have 15 minutes to talk about a dangerous world.. The 2020 presidential election won't be remembered for its lucid debate and elevated discourse. The candidates themselves bear part of the blame, but the Commission on Presidential Debates hasn't helped.

title: End the School Shutdown
summary: In-person classes turn out not to cause spikes in cases or fatality. But keeping kids home has a high cost.. Tens of millions of students started the school year completely online, including those in 13 of the 15 largest school districts in the U.S. The primary reason is concern over safety for students and staff. But recent data are shifting the discussion on school safety and infection rates of Covid-19. They argue strongly for opening K-12 schools.

title: The Case for and Against Court Packing
summary: Students debate whether Democrats should expand the bench if they win on Nov. 3.. Editor's note: In this Future View, students debate whether Democrats should pack the Supreme Court if they win big on Nov. 3. Next week we'll ask, "As the election draws near, make a final case for President Trump, Joe Biden or a third choice." Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before Oct. 27. The best responses will be published that night.

title: Suing Google Won't Help Consumers
summary: Unlike Standard Oil and U.S. Steel, its market share is beneficial to sellers and customers.. The U.S. Justice Department and 11 states filed an antitrust claim against Google Tuesday alleging illegal monopolization. The lawsuit follows the release earlier this month of a voluminous report by the House Judiciary Committee arguing that the four major U.S. internet platforms-Google, Amazon , Apple and Facebook -are monopolies and ought to be broken up. The suit against Google is the first of what will likely be many antitrust attacks on these dominant platforms.

title: How Biden Will End Fracking Without a Ban
summary: Like Obama, he'd kill the energy industry by a thousand regulatory and legislative cuts.. Joe Biden is probably telling the truth when he says he won't "ban" fracking. A president can't do that by executive order. And even if Democrats seize the Senate, a legislative ban would be politically risky. Far more likely is that a Biden administration would end fracking via indirect means, by taking a regulatory nibble here and a legislative bite there.

title: Lightning Will Have to Strike Twice for Trump to Win
summary: A repeat of 2016 would require widespread polling errors that again all work in the president's favor.. Fortunately for Donald Trump and his supporters, a lot can happen in the final two weeks of a presidential election. Four years ago at this time, Hillary Clinton was leading by 6.8 points in national polls and eventually lost. Eight years earlier, Barack Obama was leading by a nearly identical 6.9 points and won.

title: 'White Market Drugs' Review: Addiction by Prescription
summary: Major drug crises arise not in the black market but in the 'white' one, where the addictive potential of prescribed drugs is played down.. More than a century ago, the nation had its first opioid crisis. Narcotic-laced patent medicines, morphine powder and opium tinctures formed the core of a physician's pharmacopeia. Such medicines relieved the chronic wounds of Civil War veterans and treated a wide spectrum of ailments, including neuralgia, "female complaints," respiratory disorders and anxiety.

title: A Laptop Window on the Oligarchy
summary: Hunter Biden was for sale to anybody who wanted influence with his father.. Step one, help yourself to tasty assets from the public trough. Step two, figure out how to keep them.

title: Creditors Brace for Possible Debt Restructuring at Sinclair Sports Unit
summary: Sinclair's regional sports network subsidiary Diamond Sports faces coronavirus-related disruption to professional leagues and a roughly $8 billion debt load. Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc.'s regional sports business and its creditors are preparing for a possible restructuring of its roughly $8 billion debt load, a sign of the pressure on the sports industry from Covid-19, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: New U.S. Coronavirus Cases March Higher
summary: Daily Covid-19 infections top 58,000 nationwide as increases spur restrictions in Midwest. Officials in some Midwest states sounded the alarm as coronavirus-related hospitalizations climbed, while others moved to impose new restrictions amid a surge of new cases in the region.

title: Victorious ACB
summary: The Senate plans a Monday vote.. The smartest person in the room at last week's Senate judiciary committee hearings could be a Supreme Court justice as soon as next week. Jordain Carney reports in The Hill that after this Thursday's committee vote, Judge Amy Coney Barrett's nomination will receive prompt action on the Senate floor:

title: Berkshire to Pay $4.1 Million to Settle Allegations of Violating U.S. Sanctions on Iran
summary: Treasury Department says one of the conglomerate's Turkish subsidiaries sold cutting tools knowing they would be resold in Iran. Berkshire Hathaway Inc. has agreed to pay roughly $4.1 million to settle allegations that a Turkish subsidiary violated U.S. sanctions on Iran.

title: How Asian Countries Are Keeping Covid-19 Under Control
summary: While infections rise in Europe and the U.S., many Asian countries are returning to normal life. As a new wave of Covid-19 cases strike Europe and the U.S., many countries in East Asia and Southeast Asia appear to have the virus largely under control. Here's what you need to know about how the region has handled the pandemic.

title: At These Prices, Procter Is a Gamble
summary: P&G pleased investors with strong coronavirus-enhanced results, but its valuation holds up only if consumer changes prove permanent. Procter & Gamble reported strong results Tuesday as the pandemic continued to boost sales of consumer staples, but its shares are priced for the boom to never end.

title: U.S. Spy Agency Warns That Chinese Hackers Target Military, Defense Industry
summary: NSA urged the Defense Department and the defense industrial base to guard against intrusion. WASHINGTON-The National Security Agency on Tuesday warned that Chinese government hackers were taking aim at U.S. computer networks involved in national defense, characterizing the threat posed by Beijing as a critical priority in need of urgent attention.

title: Richard Branson Targets More Funds for Satellite-Launch Venture
summary: Virgin Orbit will require roughly $200 million in additional cash infusion, British entrepreneur said. Space entrepreneur Richard Branson said his satellite launch company is looking to secure additional funds even after raising $1 billion to get going.

title: Goldman to Pay $2.8 Billion, Admit Wrongdoing to Settle 1MDB Charges
summary: A bank subsidiary in Asia tied to the misconduct is expected to plead guilty this week, while the parent company will accept deferred prosecution agreement. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. will pay about $2.8 billion and admit wrongdoing to end a bribery probe that stretched from Southeast Asia to Hollywood and reinforced a reputation for scandal that the Wall Street firm has spent years trying to shed.

title: Coronavirus Delays Replacement of Statue Removed From Central Park
summary: J. Marion Sims statue was picked to be replaced after the mayor's 2017 initiative to re-examine New York City monuments. The artist selected to craft a statue to replace one of the controversial J. Marion Sims in New York City told the city council on Tuesday that officials had used the coronavirus pandemic as an "excuse for procrastination."

title: Netflix Plot Twist Was Foreshadowed
summary: Streaming giant's earlier 'pull-forward' warning proves accurate, though annual growth will still impress. Previews are often not an accurate reflection of a show's quality. But Netflix nailed it three months ago in projecting its third-quarter results.

title: Netflix Subscriber Growth Slows Amid Heightened Competition
summary: Streaming company gains 2.2 million subscribers in third quarter, lower than earlier forecast. Netflix Inc. said subscriber growth slowed in the third quarter, highlighting the fresh challenges the company faces from competitors ramping up their own streaming services as the coronavirus pandemic continues to disrupt the entertainment industry.

title: Disney Denounces California's Theme-Park Reopening Plans
summary: Covid-19 restrictions have kept Disneyland closed for seven months. Walt Disney Co. blasted California's new protocols for reopening theme parks, saying the strict guidance would significantly complicate the company's efforts to reopen Disneyland.

title: There's a Sale at Albertsons
summary: Supermarket chain's continuing sales growth and shareholder-friendly moves seem to be making investors' ears perk up. Albertsons Cos. had a tough time catching investors' attention this year. Their ears finally seem to be perking up.

title: Nigerian Protesters Killed as Soldiers Open Fire in Lagos
summary: Deadly violence comes hours after the announcement of a curfew. LAGOS, Nigeria-Several people were killed as Nigerian soldiers opened fire at a key protest site in Lagos, witnesses said, as the government sought to end two weeks of marches against police brutality that have mushroomed into broader nationwide demonstrations.

title: NYPD Plans Bigger Presence at Voting Sites on Election Day
summary: Chief of department cites 'contentious' nature of this year's presidential vote. The New York Police Department is preparing additional security measures at voting sites ahead of Election Day, police officials said Tuesday.

title: Marine General Is Relieved of Command for Repeating Racial Slur
summary: Maj. Gen. Stephen Neary was commander of Marine Corps Forces, Europe and Africa. WASHINGTON-The Marine Corps commandant relieved a top commanding general after reports he repeated a racial slur, officials said.

title: Justice Department Presses to Curtail Purdue Pharma Bankruptcy Probe
summary: Forced disclosure of Purdue documents risks deterring future government targets from cooperating, government lawyers say. The Justice Department is urging a bankruptcy judge to limit a creditor probe of OxyContin maker Purdue Pharma LP into the billions of dollars in profits collected by the Sackler family members who own the company.

title: 'Private Lives Public Spaces' Review: An Alternative Cinema History
summary: An exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art brings together 200 short films, from home movies to experimental works.. New York

title: Presidential Debates Must Follow FEC Law
summary: Your proposal for the retirement of the Commission on Presidential Debates would not comply with the law and regulations of the Federal Election Commission (FEC).. Your Oct. 17 editorial "Retire the Debate Commission" calls for the retirement of the Commission on Presidential Debates (CPD) and urges that future debates be directed by the parties. Your proposal would not comply with the law and regulations of the Federal Election Commission (FEC).

title: U.S. Should Recognize Taiwan as Sovereign
summary: As long as the U.S. continues the absurd One China policy, we cannot make a treaty of defense with the Republic of China.. Though Paul Wolfowitz makes a convincing argument that a U.S. guarantee of Taiwanese sovereignty and a military alliance with the Republic of China are the best hope for peace in the Western Pacific ("The Korean War's Lesson for Taiwan," op-ed, Oct. 14), he omits one vital point. Nations make treaties with their sovereign peers, not rebellious provincial governments. As long as the U.S. continues the absurd One China policy, we cannot make a treaty of defense with the Republic of China.

title: Goodbye, 'Bye Bye Birdie'
summary: A survey of the musicals most often produced by American high schools suggests that golden-age Broadway shows may not have a place in the future of professional theater..

title: Harvey Weinstein's Victims Should Vote on Settlement Offer, Judge Says
summary: Lawyers liquidating Harvey Weinstein's former studio want his accusers to vote on a settlement that would create a $17 million victims fund. A Delaware bankruptcy judge said that women who allege they were harassed or sexually assaulted by Harvey Weinstein should be permitted to vote on a proposed civil settlement creating a $17 million victims' compensation fund.

title: U.S. v. Google: A Guide to the Government's Lawsuit
summary: Some key arguments from Justice Department's complaint and what company says in response. The Justice Department filed an antitrust lawsuit Tuesday alleging Google is taking illegal steps to preserve a monopoly in internet search and search advertising, claims the company vehemently denies. Here are some key arguments from the government's complaint and what the company says in response:

title: Make U.S. Railroads More Price Competitive
summary: There is no doubt that the Staggers Act helped save the nation's rail network from collapse. But more work is needed to realize the landmark law's vision of a competitive rail industry.. In "When Democrats Were Deregulators" (op-ed, Oct. 14), Association of American Railroads CEO Ian Jefferies praises the Staggers Rail Act for leading to "targeted deregulation." Unfortunately for the businesses that rely on freight rail, the term "targeted" is code for preserving certain outdated regulatory policies that favor and protect the railroads from truly competing in the marketplace.

title: Stocks Jump on Optimism on Stimulus
summary: Additional government aid from American households and businesses hangs on whether a deal can be struck Tuesday. U.S. stocks rose Tuesday on optimism that Congress would reach an agreement on a spending package to support American households and businesses through the pandemic.

title: The German Marshall Fund Defends Report
summary: We will continue to champion ideas that support democracy, human rights and international cooperation.. The German Marshall Fund of the United States (GMF) is a nonpartisan policy organization committed to the principles of democracy, human rights and international cooperation. We were disappointed to see the Journal's Oct. 15 editorial "Facebook's Conservative Emergency" criticizing one of GMF's latest efforts to identify the cause of and solutions to disinformation, a serious threat to these values.

title: Feinstein Faces Questions About Judiciary Committee Leadership
summary: Senator would be first woman to lead panel if Democrats win the majority, but progressives want her to step aside. WASHINGTON-Progressive groups' calls for Sen. Dianne Feinstein to step down from her position as top Democrat on the Judiciary Committee have put a fresh spotlight on who will lead the powerful panel if the party wins back the Senate.

title: Moody's Downgrades U.K. Banks
summary: Credit-rating firm reduces long-term issuer ratings of U.K. units of HSBC, Lloyds and Banco Santander. Moody's Investors Service downgraded the credit ratings of three banks in the U.K. following a cut to the nation's sovereign debt rating last week.

title: Uber Founder Turns Real-Estate Mogul for Ghost Kitchen Startup
summary: WSJ analysis shows entities tied to Travis Kalanick spent more than $130 million on property acquisitions for CloudKitchens. The former chief executive of Uber Technologies Inc. has been quietly assembling a mini real-estate empire over the past two years, acquiring closed restaurants, auto-body shops and warehouses for use in his new ghost kitchen venture.

title: Zoom's CFO Looks to OnZoom to Grow Revenue Opportunities
summary: Kelly Steckelberg is banking on the new events platform to boost the company's reach and revenues. Zoom Video Communications Inc.'s finance chief is working to monetize a new events platform, part of a broader effort to expand the company's product offering.

title: Bar Hopping (Wednesday Crossword, October 21)
Oyo CEO Says Company's Business Has Rebounded From Spring Nadir
summary: Recovery was buoyed by travelers staying in small properties in Southeast Asia and Europe, Chief Executive Ritesh Agarwal says. India-based hotel startup Oyo Hotels & Homes has seen a key financial figure rebound to 20% below pre-pandemic levels after falling as much as 60% earlier in the year, Chief Executive Ritesh Agarwal said.

title: Clearview Moves to Limit Risk of Police Abuse
summary: Company adds new compliance features to help ensure ethical law-enforcement use of its controversial technology. Clearview AI Inc., the controversial startup that provides facial-recognition technology to law enforcement, is rolling out new compliance features aimed at preventing abuse of the technology, Chief Executive Hoan Ton-That said Tuesday.

title: Google's Exclusive Search Deals With Apple at Heart of U.S. Lawsuit
summary: Hitting 'Code Red'; lucrative partnership between tech giants in the antitrust spotlight. Inside Google, they called the scenario "Code Red," so stark was the prospect of losing the search engine's lucrative pipeline from Apple Inc.'s iPhone.

title: The Burden of Health Care Costs Can Make Marriage More Enticing
summary: Young Americans already face tough financial terrain, from student debt to rising housing costs. Young adults are often in bad financial health. The ability to get health insurance coverage through a spouse can make marriage more enticing, particularly in the face of burgeoning student debt, rising housing costs and stagnant wages. In 2019, 18% of adults had unpaid debt from their own medical care or from medical care for a family member and a quarter of adults skipped medical care because they were unable to afford the cost, a Federal Reserve survey found. Wall Street Journal reporter Francesca Fontana writes in this column that concerns about health care costs partly prompted her decision to tie the knot, enabling her husband to be on her health insurance. "I couldn't think of a better way to start off our union, by ensuring that my partner can take care of himself, in sickness and in health," writes Fontana.

title: U.S. Banking Regulator Backs New Liquidity Requirements
summary: FDIC board votes 3-1 to approve final rule for net stable funding ratio. WASHINGTON-U.S. financial regulators moved Tuesday to adopt new rules obliging large banks to hold enough funding to meet their needs for up to a year.

title: California Community Colleges Get $100 Million Gift for Financial Aid
summary: Jay Pritzker Foundation's record donation to cover scholarships, emergency assistance for students. The family foundation of Hyatt Hotels founder Jay Pritzker has pledged $100 million to California's community colleges, the largest gift so far in that sector of higher education.

title: 'The Queen's Gambit' Review: A Winning Chess Thriller
summary: A young chess savant finds herself a propaganda tool in this novelistic Cold War tale.. It took this viewer about seven consecutive hours to watch all seven episodes of "The Queen's Gambit," and while this may constitute all the review some readers need to get on board, others might also like to know what the miniseries is about. In a word, chess-though that's a bit like saying "Hamlet" is about Danish royal succession, or "The Wizard of Oz" is about meteorology.

title: Several Lawmakers Denied Access to Postal Facilities
summary: Democrats said visits are needed to ensure mail-in ballot safety; GOP calls effort political stunt. Efforts by some members of Congress to observe firsthand how mail is being processed at large facilities in the final weeks of the election have been blocked-a policy departure by the U.S. Postal Service for visits that were once routinely approved, the lawmakers said.

title: Many Workers Gave Up Looking for Jobs in September
summary: Declining unemployment rates in states masked signs of labor-market deterioration, data suggest. Workers gave up looking for jobs across the U.S. in September, with the size of the labor force shrinking in more than half of the 30 states in which unemployment rates fell last month, Labor Department data released Tuesday showed.

title: U.S., Russia Near Deal to Extend Nuclear Treaty and Freeze Warheads
summary: Breakthrough on New START agreement would buy time for a future pact that the Trump administration says should include China. The U.S. and Russia are on the verge of an arms-control deal that would freeze the number of nuclear warheads on each side and extend the New START agreement for a year, a senior Trump administration official said Tuesday.

title: Google Critics Cheer DOJ Suit, but Skeptics Question Motives
summary: Reactions foreshadow lengthy debate over merits of the enforcement action. WASHINGTON-The Justice Department's antitrust lawsuit against Alphabet Inc.'s Google drew bipartisan praise from lawmakers and cheers from the company's competitors, while prompting skepticism and accusations of political bias from larger technology companies and critics of the Trump administration.

title: Volunteers to Be Infected With Coronavirus in U.K. Vaccine Trials
summary: Controversial 'human challenge' trial would require injecting healthy humans with virus to gauge effectiveness of vaccines. LONDON-U.K. researchers plan to start infecting healthy volunteers with tightly controlled doses of the coronavirus in early 2021 in what they called a first-of-its-kind effort to more rapidly gauge the effectiveness of multiple vaccines against Covid-19.

title: 'American Values' Portend Trump's Defeat
summary: Voters in an annual survey have soured on him and move toward the left on policy.. Democrats and Republicans are competing to define the agenda in the waning days of the 2020 campaign, but voters have reached their own conclusions. Americans rate the coronavirus pandemic as more critical than any other issue, and they aren't pleased with how it has been handled. This is one of the principal findings of the annual American Values Survey, released on Monday and conducted by the Public Religion Research Institute in partnership with the Brookings Institution, where I am a scholar.

title: Prisoners Don't Need Covid Stimulus Checks
summary: What they require is policy reforms. Money would feed the prison black market, which can have deadly consequences.. The Internal Revenue Service will soon send checks to prison. A federal district judge last week ordered the Internal Revenue Service not to withhold stimulus payments of $1,200 to 85,000 state and federal inmates. Those who didn't get a check are invited to file a 2019 tax return so they can collect.

title: Traders Pick Up Pieces After European Exchange Outages
summary: Glitch left traders with unintended exposures and unsure whether a portion of the trades they placed Monday had gone through. Traders and investors across Europe scrambled Tuesday to understand how a series of failures at one of the continent's biggest exchange-operators had affected their positions in stocks, bonds and derivatives.

title: Intel Sees Opportunity in U.S.-China Tensions' Impact on Supply Chains
summary: CEO Bob Swan said sale of flash memory business would help unlock capital to pursue fast-growing areas such as 5G, AI computing. Intel Corp. could see new business opportunities from a bifurcation of tech supply chains amid growing tensions between the U.S. and China, the chip maker's Chief Executive Bob Swan said.

title: Aluminum Prices Surge as Chinese Demand Accelerates
summary: Stockpiles of the metal have been declining with the Chinese economy roaring. Aluminum prices are hovering around 18-month highs as investors bet strong Chinese buying and improving industrial demand will see the metal catch up with its base-metal peers.

title: IBM Hopes to Double Sales at Red Hat in Next Three Years
summary: Company looking to bolster growth through a greater focus on cloud-computing. International Business Machines Corp. hopes to double sales at its Red Hat open-source software unit in the next three years as Chief Executive Arvind Krishna aims to restore growth at the tech titan.

title: Google Is the Only Big Tech Priced for Trouble
summary: Antitrust suit against search giant puts tech investors on notice. Google has turned out to be first in the federal government's firing line. Its big tech peers may pay a bigger price for waiting their turn.

title: Travelers Is Ready for Post-Pandemic Journey
summary: Strong insurance pricing is helping Travelers and other insurers combat pressure of superlow interest rates. Travelers Cos. is moving in the right direction, but it hasn't arrived there yet.

title: UBS Profit Doubles on Trading Surge
summary: Lender posts strong performance at investment bank and wealth-management units as Sergio Ermotti nears end of term in charge. UBS Group AG said its net profit nearly doubled in the third quarter on a surge in client trading and deal making, freeing up cash for dividends and share buybacks despite the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Uber Weighs California Overhaul if Ballot Measure on Workers Fails
summary: Ride-sharing service says prices for riders will rise if company isn't exempted from state law reclassifying drivers as employees. Uber Technologies Inc. is considering an overhaul of its business in California if voters reject a ballot measure that would prevent the ride-hailing company's drivers from being classified as employees.

title: Before Peter Frampton Made It Big, He Was Mesmerized by David Bowie
summary: The English rocker recalls the first time he saw the legendary musician perform, and cutting his teeth on the banjolele.. Peter Frampton, 70, is a rock guitarist, singer-songwriter and producer whose "Frampton Comes Alive!" was No. 1 for 10 weeks on the Billboard album chart in 1976. He is the author of the memoir "Do You Feel Like I Do?" (Hachette). He spoke with Marc Myers.

title: Travelers More Than Doubles Quarterly Income
summary: Property-casualty insurance company reported just under $400 million in pretax catastrophe losses. Property-casualty insurer Travelers Cos. more than doubled its net income in the third quarter, benefiting from auto policyholders driving fewer miles and increased premium rates.

title: Seasonal Hazard for Working at Home: Leaf Blowers
summary: Resume Subscription. Millions of American workers last spring thought the silver lining of quarantine would at least be exchanging the hustle and bustle of the office for the relative peace and quiet of home. Then yard work season began.

title: States Prepare to File Own Antitrust Cases Against Google
summary: At least two overlapping groups of attorneys general are investigating the company. WASHINGTON-More antitrust cases are likely to be filed against Alphabet Inc.'s Google soon by state attorneys general, even though partisan-tinged wrangling has clouded the path forward.

title: Bolivians Embrace Another Socialist After Ousting Evo Morales
summary: Conservative party took 14 years to take power from the leftist icon and 11 months to be voted out. In the 11 months since President Evo Morales resigned and fled Bolivia, the right-wing interim government, seeking to undo his policies while dealing with scandal and pandemic, failed to get voters on its side-paving the way for his left-wing party to retake power.

title: How Next-Door Neighbors With Opposing Political Views Stayed Friends
summary: Troubled by the national discourse, the Gateses and Mitchells use signs to 'send a message' of civility. The Mitchells, lifelong Democrats, planted a Joe Biden sign in the front yard of their suburban Pittsburgh home. The Gateses, who live next door and are lifelong Republicans, put a Donald Trump sign in theirs.

title: Jamal Khashoggi's Fiancée Sues Saudi Crown Prince in U.S. Court
summary: The civil suit adds to the challenges Riyadh faces in trying to move past the killing of the slain dissident. The fiancée of slain Saudi dissident Jamal Khashoggi has filed a lawsuit against Saudi Arabia's crown prince in a U.S. court charging that the kingdom's de facto ruler ordered the killing.

title: The Ultimate Simulator for Covid Times: Sitting on an Airplane
summary: New AMC videogame simulates an uneventful trans-Atlantic flight. Some people miss traveling so much that they are paying for it.. Can it get more bizarre than hopping on flights to nowhere to reminisce about cramped airplane seats? Yes: doing that virtually.

title: Apprenticeships Are Paying Off Big for Some, Study Finds
summary: Research into a program that pairs employers with community colleges suggests four-year degrees aren't the only path to higher salaries. Apprenticeship-style programs are paying off for graduates, who typically earn nearly six figures within five years of graduation, a study by Opportunity America and the Brookings Institution found.

title: Racial-Discrimination Settlements Usually Came With an NDA. That's Changing.
summary: Resume Subscription. Alex Gumbs says he wants to settle the racial-discrimination complaint he brought this year against his former employer, Medtronic PLC. He also doesn't want to be quiet about what he says he experienced as a Black employee at the medical-device maker.

title: Israel, U.A.E. to Allow Citizens Visa-Free Travel
summary: The agreement is the first such arrangement between Israel and an Arab state. TEL AVIV-Israel and the United Arab Emirates agreed to allow their citizens reciprocal visa-free travel as direct flights begin, the first such arrangement between Israel and an Arab state aimed at bolstering business and tourism ties.

title: U.S. Broadens Sanctions to Thwart Completion of Russian Gas Pipeline
summary: New measures target companies that would provide services or funding for vessels working on Nord Stream 2. WASHINGTON-The State Department broadened the scope of sanctions targeting an unfinished Russian-backed natural-gas pipeline that has been a source of tension between Germany, Russia and the U.S.

title: Starbucks, Johnson & Johnson, Twitter: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven companies whose stocks moved on the week's news. JPMorgan Chase & Co.

title: A Year After Fetching $17 Million, a Vail Mountain Home Lists for $32 Million
summary: Oil and gas executive Matthew Fleeger says he spent roughly $7 million renovating the roughly 11,000-square-foot property. A recently remodeled mountain-style stone home with wood details and panoramic views of the Gore mountain range in Vail, Colo., is coming on the market for $32 million. If it traded for close to that price, the home would be among the most expensive ever sold in the Vail area.

title: This Vail Home Could Be One of the Area's Priciest
summary: Inside the 11,000-square-foot home of Matthew Fleeger, an oil and gas company executive. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Fed Official Says Market Turmoil Triggered by Covid-19 Revealed Fragile Nonbank System
summary: 'While swift and decisive policy action succeeded in calming markets, this does not mean that our work is complete,' says central banker. WASHINGTON-The market turmoil triggered by the coronavirus pandemic early this year uncovered weaknesses in the U.S. financial system that regulators are seeking to fix, said Randal Quarles, the Federal Reserve's vice chairman for supervision.

title: Supreme Court Allows Extension for Mail-In Ballots in Pennsylvania
summary: Order provides win for Democrats in battleground state. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court on Monday refused to disturb a ruling by Pennsylvania's highest court that extended the battleground state's deadline for accepting mail-in ballots, a win for Democrats that gives voters more time to navigate postal delays and avoid in-person voting.

title: Nearly 25% of New York City Transit Workers Cited Covid-19 Infections, Study Says
summary: New York state officials said in May that about 14% of a sample of MTA employees had tested positive for virus antibodies. New York City subway and bus workers might have been infected by the new coronavirus at rates higher than previously thought, according to results of a survey released Tuesday by researchers.

title: Google's Long Tail of Government Probes
summary: Google spent years under investigation for possible anticompetitive behavior before the Justice Department filed its antitrust suit.

title: Covid-19's Global Divide: As West Reels, Asia Keeps Virus at Bay
summary: Coronavirus cases are surging again across Europe and the U.S., but infections have stayed at low levels in most Asian countries. While a surge in coronavirus infections is forcing U.S. states and European countries to shut down bars, open field hospitals and limit social gatherings to small groups of people, such measures are becoming distant memories in much of Asia.

title: P&G and Reckitt Clean Up on Pandemic-Driven Hygiene
summary: Global sales jump as consumers shift from stocking up during lockdowns to buying pricier home products. Procter & Gamble Co. reported its biggest global sales increase in 15 years as the world's consumers spent more to keep their homes and themselves clean during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Review of iPhone 12 and iPhone 12 Pro
summary: Don't consider Apple's latest iPhones for the superfast 5G network connection, but for the best design in years and a great set of cameras. Let's start with the good news: The iPhone 12, the first with 5G, is indeed the fastest 5G smartphone. The speeds will knock your masks off, as we say in 2020.

title: Coronavirus Gives Big Boost to 'Little Libraries'
summary: New Yorkers set up free miniature libraries in parks, public squares, with pace accelerating over past year. When a public-library branch in Long Island City, Queens, lost its lease and closed last winter, Frank Wu took action. The 35-year-old software company salesman and father installed a "little library" in nearby Court Square Park-a small, glass-fronted cabinet mounted in a planter festooned with ivy. Now, all day long, residents and office workers stop by to donate books and help themselves to free reads. "It wasn't that much work," says Mr. Wu.

title: Joe Biden Fends Off President Trump's 2016 Playbook
summary: Despite attacks, the Democratic nominee has a higher favorability rating than either the president or Hillary Clinton had in 2016.. WASHINGTON-President Trump is dipping into his 2016 playbook, using paid advertising, his Twitter feed, campaign rallies and White House events to attack Democratic nominee Joe Biden over his political record and his mental stability, among other things.

title: Intel's Deal With SK Hynix Shows Limited Space Left for Chip Makers
summary: South Korean company to control close to one-quarter of the NAND flash memory market. SEOUL-Intel Corp.'s $9 billion deal to sell most of its memory-chip business to a South Korean company accelerates the industry consolidation around a ubiquitous technology component.

title: IBM, Parsley Energy, Logitech, Moderna: What to Watch When the Market Opens Today
summary: Stock futures pointed to gains after the New York opening bell ahead of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's deadline for stimulus-package talks. Here's what we are watching as markets kick into gear Tuesday.

title: Screens Before Bed Are OK for Kids-Just Keep It Calm
summary: Researchers say it's likely more helpful to block out stressful content in the hour before bedtime than to shut down screens completely. Two experiences have become pretty universal during the pandemic: Screen time has skyrocketed and sleep is disrupted. But is there a correlation between the two?

title: The Alfa Romeo Model Made Famous by Dustin Hoffman
summary: Millions remember the Duetto Spider from 'The Graduate.' This Florida graphic artist found his own Duetto in an old garage.. Clark Daily, 56, a 3-D graphic artist with Lockheed Martin living in Maitland, Fla., on his 1967 Alfa Romeo Duetto Spider, as told to A.J. Baime.

title: Lysol Sales Boom Is Part Luck, Part Elbow Grease
summary: Reckitt Benckiser grew its third-quarter sales by 13%; pandemic-related demand has been strong, but the business is also better operationally. Reckitt Benckiser 's chief executive might be one of the luckiest bosses around. But a pandemic-led spike in demand for cleaning products like Dettol and Lysol isn't the only explanation for the packaged-goods company's polished performance this year.

title: New York Faces $59 Billion Revenue Shortfall
summary: Gov. Cuomo says services will be cut and taxes will increase if Congress doesn't pass another relief package. ALBANY, N.Y.-New York governments and authorities are projecting $59 billion of revenue shortfalls through 2022 because of the continuing coronavirus crisis, one of the deepest funding holes of any state.

title: Writers Rumaan Alam and Bryan Washington on Capturing Reality in Their Fiction
summary: The authors of Leave the World Behind and Memorial, two of this season's most exciting new books, discuss their work, the paradox of realism and upending commercial publishing.. Writers Bryan Washington and Rumaan Alam have never met in person, though they're intimately familiar with each other's work. Alam, 43, who lives in Brooklyn, has been teaching Washington's 2019 collection of short stories, Lot, to his class at Columbia University, and Washington, 27, who teaches at Rice University and lives in Houston, read Alam's recent bestseller, Leave the World Behind, before it was published earlier this month. As their novels-both with screen adaptations on the way-are out this month, their worlds are finally coming together.

title: Photos: Here's to You, Alfa Romeo
summary: A gearhead with a thing for Italian cars shows off his 1967 Duetto Spider, the model featured in 'The Graduate' with Dustin Hoffman. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Main Street Cinemas Teeter On the Brink; Puerto Rico Election Preview; Tilton Can't Stop Rand McNally Sale
summary: Resume Subscription. Good day. Movie-theater companies of all sizes are under unprecedented financial strain. Pandemic restrictions are keeping patrons away. Studios aren't releasing flicks. And streaming movies are gaining in popularity for film lovers stuck at home. But for family-owned operators, the problems are particularly acute and personal. WSJ Pro Bankruptcy looks at several theater owners on the brink of bankruptcy as the pandemic drags on.

title: U.S. Charges Six Russian Intelligence Officers With Hacking
summary: Indictment links Russians to several prominent cyberattacks in recent years, including the global 2017 NotPetya attack. WASHINGTON-Federal prosecutors unsealed charges against six Russian intelligence officers accused of engaging in some of the most destructive cyberattacks of recent years, including operations that knocked out Ukraine's energy grid, exposed emails from the French president's party and damaged global systems in the costly 2017 NotPetya attack.

title: Pot Stocks Go on a Chilled-Out Election Rally
summary: Shares in cannabis companies have risen as polls point to a Democratic victory in November, but investors are less excitable than in 2016. A victory for the Democratic Party in next month's presidential election would be a game changer for the cannabis industry. Despite their reputation for overexuberance, pot investors are reacting with level heads.

title: The New York Jets Hit Rock Bottom-Even for the Jets
summary: The Jets are the last winless team in the NFL in 2020. Sinking to the bottom of the league took years of mismanagement-producing a low-point for football's perennial punching bag.. Over the last two decades, the New York Jets have experienced their share of humiliations. The best coach in football history, Bill Belichick, resigned on a napkin at his introductory news conference in 2000. Geno Smith, their starting quarterback in 2015, had his jaw broken by a teammate. One play was so comically embarrassing it's simply known as the Butt Fumble.

title: Haunted Houses, Bingo Games, Covid-19 Testing. Parking Lots See More Action Than Adjoining Shops.
summary: Landlords are thankful for activities that bring in additional revenue or foot traffic. Parking lots tend to be little more than an afterthought for real-estate investors. But during the pandemic, asphalt has never been hotter.

title: Commercial REITs for Small Investors See Increasing Demand
summary: Nontraded real-estate investment trusts are again bringing in money after a pandemic slowdown. A new type of commercial real-estate fund that targets small investors is raking in money again after demand cooled during the early months of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Europe's Riskiest Countries Find Debt Markets Wide Open
summary: Greece's borrowing costs shrank to the tightest point relative to Germany since 2009, a flashback to before last decade's debt crisis exposed fault lines across the Continent. Borrowing costs for Europe's riskiest governments are hitting record lows as investors bet on newfound European political cohesion. Also pushing yields lower are U.S. election dynamics reverberating across the Atlantic.

title: Presidential Candidates' Microphones to Be Muted in Parts of Final Debate
summary: President Trump and Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden will be silenced while opponent gives opening statement at the start of each segment. WASHINGTON-The presidential candidates' microphones will be muted during parts of their final debate Thursday as organizers seek to limit the interruptions and crosstalk that marked their previous meeting.

title: Intel's SK Hynix Deal Will Make Good Memories
summary: The sale of Intel's NAND memory chip unit makes good sense for both parties. Intel 's origin as a memory-chip company is already a distant memory. Its latest deal just confirms that-and brings much-needed consolidation to the industry.

title: Microsoft Teams With SpaceX to Push Cloud Battle With Amazon Into Orbit
summary: The space-cloud initiative is targeting military and commercial customers and comes after Amazon announced its own space effort. Microsoft Corp. is teaming with Elon Musk's SpaceX and others as the software giant opens a new front in its cloud-computing battle with Amazon.com Inc., targeting space customers.

title: China Is Experiencing a Boom in Share Sales
summary: Local markets are outshining global peers, aided by the country's economic recovery. China is claiming a record proportion of global initial public offerings and other debuts, aided by buoyant markets, a new tech board and companies seeking listings closer to home.

title: Curbside Popcorn and 'Hocus Pocus': Small Movie Theaters Try Anything to Survive
summary: Though many cinemas have been allowed to reopen at limited capacity, most moviegoers are staying away, partly because Hollywood has postponed big releases. Lynn Kinsella, the co-owner of an upstate New York movie theater, started selling popcorn curbside after coronavirus restrictions barred her and other small cinemas in the state from showing movies. But the snack sales only made up a fraction of the missing box-office money.

title: Foxconn's Terry Gou Says Big Wisconsin Project Hinges on State Aid
summary: 'Foxconn will work as a partner with those who treat the company as a partner,' tech founder says. Foxconn Technology Group founder Terry Gou said the company's commitment to a multibillion-dollar factory investment in Wisconsin hinges on whether government officials deliver promised support for the project.

summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.
